title: Please identify FAO SCHWARZ LOGO FONT
content:
Does anyone know what font was used to create the FAO Schwarz logo?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [FAO.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345/http:/typophile.com/files/FAO.jpg) | 12.92 KB |

 [‹ anyone know what font this is](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345/http:/typophile.com/node/41855 "Go to previous forum topic") [Ornament ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345/http:/typophile.com/node/41847 "Go to next forum topic")
author: jameyw

comments.content:
Forgive me! I can’t resist this :-)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345im_/http:/typophile.com/files/schwartzfao.gif)

ChrisL

It look like [Treacyfaces’](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345/http:/www.treacyfaces.com/) Arrow to me, possibly with some modifications. (Sorry, no direct link to a font sample, but they do have an [online sample setter](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345/http:/www.treacyfaces.com/sample.html).)

I know it’s not this, but wouldn’t it be nice if they used Nick Shinn’s Beaufort instead?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907045345im_/http:/typophile.com/files/shinn_beaufort.png)

It’s a bastardized version of TF Arrow and Beaufort. TF Arrow and Beufort were used as the template and the points were changed to make the current FAO logo (see the “W” which was modified) which apparently has more than five versions of itself. Ironically, breaking the rules of it’s own brand.

The logo reminds me very much of what Microsoft did to Helvetica, they changed some points and call their version Arial. It’s a cheap-ass design copout that is becoming all to familiar in the digital age.
